subject: No Surprises
event: Black Monday is here, and true to expectations, the Jets fired John Idzik and Rex Ryan. Idzik was a disaster from day one, and set the franchise back years.  He did leave plenty of salary cap room for his successor, which is about the only good thing that can be said for him.  He was bad at drafting and worse at free agency. Firing Rex was a huge mistake, though.  Gang Green will have a hard time finding anyone even half as good.  All that talk about Jim Harbaugh was as empty as I suspected.  Rex will turn up again as head coach, and soon, and will lead his new team to the playoffs... sooner than the Jets will be returning there, I fear. So the Jets need a new GM, a new head coach, and... most of all... a quarterback.  It makes no difference who occupies the front office and stands on the sideline so long as Geno Smith and Michael Vick are the choices behind center.  With Rex and his defense, we only needed an adequate quarterback to win; without them, we need someone good enough to go up against Tom Brady twice a year. The future does not look bright.

comments.article: With your Jets fan perspective, is there any reason the Bears SHOULDN'T hire Rex Ryan as their next head coach? He's currently my favorite for the job of replacing Trestman.
comments.subject: Rex Ryan

comments.article:
Rex would be a great pick for the Bears. Your defense is one of your biggest problems, and Rex would turn it around, restore the Monster of the Midway to their former glory.

Your other big problem is Cutler, however. Not sure Rex can fix that one. He was not able to fix Sanchez or Geno Smith, for sure.
comments.subject: Re: Rex Ryan

comments.article:
The talking heads on ESPN seem to think that Rex will turn up again as a head coach, probably sooner rather than later. The consensus seemed to be that the Falcons and he would be a good match.

One thing that is in no doubt as far as I can discern, Ryan was well beloved by his players.

Hi George.  Not a Jets fan (as a Dolfan, I actually enjoy the Jets' struggles, although yesterday was no bueno), but the problem goes beyond even the quarterback.  The Jets will have either the fifth or the sixth pick and seem likely to take Marcus Mariota or Jameis Winston, but neither will solve their problems.  So long as Woody Johnson owns the team, the toxic environment will persist.  His history will lead to the top GM candidates passing on the gig, which in turn will make it hard for coaches and quarterbacks to thrive.  Unless Woody commits to letting good people do their jobs instead of interfering with the back pages in mind, nothing will change for this team.  While my own perpetually mediocre team struggles to find itself, that will be the source of my football-watching joy every fall.
comments.subject: The fish rots from the head down

comments.article: I don't think we can land Mariota with the sixth pick.  Jameis Winston might fall to us, but picking him would be another type of disaster.  New York City would only magnify his off the field issues.  The Jets would be better served by picking up some veteran journeyman quarterback in free agency.
comments.subject: Re: The fish rots from the head down
Re: The fish rots from the head down
Re: The fish rots from the head down
Re: The fish rots from the head down

comments.article: Who are you rooting for in the playoffs...if any team at all? Even though I'm a massive Cowboys fan, I always root for the NFC East teams to have deep playoff runs to make the division, as a whole, look better. I only hate the Giants, Redskins and Eagles in the regular season.
comments.subject: Playoffs

comments.article: I hate the Cowboys all the time, and will be rooting against them... and against the Patriots in the AFC.
comments.subject: Re: Playoffs

comments.article:
As an Eagles fan, I too am disappointed by this season. But hey, there's still some great football to watch. Good luck to the Jets next season.

First time commenter and a huge fan of your work. Happy holidays and best wishes for a great 2015.
comments.subject: I sympathize

comments.article: If the Cowboys win the Superbowl this year I am going to be depressed. We can not let Walder Frey (I mean Jerry Jones) win a Superbowl.
comments.subject: NFL: Playoffs

comments.article:
Hello! Your entry got to top-25 of the most popular entries in LiveJournal!
Learn more about LiveJournal Ratings in FAQ.

Sorry to hear that. I know that you were hoping the Jets would keep Rex beyond this season.

I wouldn't be surprised to see Rex land in San Fran. I've heard they have a coaching vacancy...

Maybe the new regime will ship Vick AND Geno to the Bills.
It was pretty obvious corporate needed to do something drastic. Best of luck getting a dependable QB - we've been trying for decades with no success.

It's unfortunate the season ended how it did, but I think the Jets have a very good defensive line to build off of. If they can draft a few good corners they'll have one of the better defenses in the league. Though with Rex gone I'm not sure how they'll do next season. As far as the offense goes I think Vick and Geno should battle it out, I'm biased towards Vick though. At least the Giants look kind of promising with Odell Beckham.
comments.subject: Bad Season

comments.article: Vick is done.
comments.subject: Re: Bad Season

comments.article:
Believe me when I say I feel you. The only thing more depressing after another losing season is not having a Qb, and we have never had one. I feel a bit like the north...Leaderless. Speaking of the seven kingdoms how is writing going?

Hope it goes well and at least occupies your time away from thinking about the depressing Jets and Giants seasons. There's always next year.

Thanks for you continued fan interactions.

Brandon Campbell
comments.subject: Texan Fan

comments.article:
We did just respond to each other, about a week ago in regards to Rex's value as a headcoach, but as fruitless a task as it may be I feel I must try to console & corral you into believing this is for the best.

To do so, I will point to my favorite and your most despised coach as an example. Billy B was a bit slow on the uptake defensively, as far as personel goes. One might have even called the man stubborn, but he did finally come around and start drafting players that were quickier and more classically athletic rather than the vince wilforks of the world. He adapted to the rules changes over time and put more emphasis on the skills that take advantage of those rules changes. Granted, he has been pretty horrendeous at drafting anyone that plays on the outside of the field.

Rex is still trying to win games the way his dad wanted to win (damn near 30 years ago)....Ground and pound on offense and play tough nosed defense. You can not win (at least not in the regular season) with a run-first offense anymore. Say what you will about Idzik, but I think you might be a bit naive in thinking Rex didn't have a significant say in the QB's that were drafted (the Sanchize for sure).

The Jets have shown nothing on Offense for his entire tenure, and been in the bottom third statistically (even in the "good" years). Rex gets guys to play hard for him, but he doesn't exemplify the steadiness that is needed to show a QB how to lead a team.

He very may well end up on a team with an established QB that just needs someone to come in and be a glorified defensive coordinator (Atlanta???) and win some games, but it wont last. It will never last with him. Players' coaches never work out in the long run.
comments.subject: Futile Effort But I'll Try

comments.article:
You win or you die.

4-12? This decision was obvious.

I cannot in good conscience watch the Jets so long as Michael Vick is still signed on to their team.
comments.subject: You win or you die

comments.article: Mr. Martin, as a science fiction author and football fan did you have an special interest in the Bitcoin Bowl? (Took place ion December 26, 2014, NC State vs. UCF) What's your stance on bitcoin, by the way?
I don't think I have a stance on bitcoin.  And I don't follow college football, just the pros.
I feel for you with the Jets woes, but Seattle to win it all again!
comments.subject: super bowl

comments.article: As a Patriots fan I'm happy to see Rex leave the division. While I hate the Jets, the games between his Jets and the Patriots were always great contests to watch. His defense has done the best against Brady and co. and most games were tense affairs. He leaves NY with a lot of respect from this Pats fan, and I agree he leaves big defensive shoes to fill.
Leave those weak jets and remember tywins words :some wars are won with Ravens!!!
i just submitted my resume for the GM spot.

Although it will be hard to find an improvement at this point it seems to me that Rex has given the Jets everything he had to give. Maybe he'll see greener grass somewhere else.

The team was well balanced in his first 3 to 4 years but then the decline started. A year before Idzik arrived.

It was strange to me that he can't find a QB or offensive talent in any of the drafts (it's hard to imagine that he didn't influence drafting and left everything to the GM's) or hire good OC's in those declining years of his tenure.

He's a great defensive mind but it seems to me that he doesn't even want to talk offense at all and that may have been his demise through the years.

Even Evil Little Bill who was a brilliant DC when the Giants were a pack of beasts more than 20 years ago adapted and whiffed in more than one place before starting the Empire in New England. Rex just plainly ignored offense.

And then put QB's in almost impossible positions without virtually any talent on skilled positions.

And the franchise signed to many 'knuckleheads' (Holmes, Edwards 2.0 and Harvin to name a few) during his tenure.

Jets are a polar opposite to the Giants (organizationally) and for a while (since I can remember) they have been unstable. Form Woody to the field, with a few exceptions.
comments.subject: Jets woes

comments.article: I see Lovie Smith is available, so perhaps he may be able to head the Jets into a winning season. Though it will likely be a long road ahead. Trust me, as a Lions fan I have witnessed numerous coaches, and GMs as well as QBs. I see a slew of college coaches that may have potential.
comments.subject: Lovie Smith?

comments.article: I thought for some reason Lovie Smith was available - but he isn't. So please forgive my last comment since it is greatly invalid. Maybe I thought it was 2013 or I was in a time warp or something...
comments.subject: Ugh Lovie Smith

comments.article: Rex may be a fine defensive mind, but he wasn't going to win in New York. We Lions fans witnessed first hand how even a good coach (Jim Schwartz) can lose the team. Jim Caldwell took the same losing players and turned them back into a playoff team. A new coach and a new QB and the Jets will be back on track, although winning at the end probably cost you Mariota and Winston.
comments.subject: For the best

comments.upictitle: ryan, diesel, ty johnson, dirk vargas, ect.. ect..: Syd
comments.article:
I bet the Jets could land Jay Cutler... haha, just kidding! No, but seriously, I think Rex was unfairly fired. The GM never gave him a quarterback that could be considered consistent. Sanchez seemed to be too wrapped up in the glamour of the position, and Geno is far better suited for a back up. However, I don't think the current situation is as dire long term as you might think. I don't see Brady playing past 3, 4 years. By then, if the Jets can find a decent quarterback they can develop, and that's a big if, they could be in a position to be top dog.

BTW, I know this is off topic, but any chance of a New Years sample chapter like the past few years?

Although a Giants fan, I'm going to pose something to you for QB that would actually be helpful. What about Colt McCoy as a stop gap? You could draft a solid QB in the 2nd or 3rd round and groom him. McCoy might be short, but he's a leader, and that's something the Jets sorely are lacking on the field.
comments.subject: QBing for the Jets

comments.article:
You assume the Redskins are going to let him go. I thought he was the new starter there, supplanting RGIII.

If we want a young QB to groom, we have one on the roster in Matt Simms. I'd like to see him given a chance. He might not win a SB like his father, but his brother was a solid middle range NFL QB as well, I think MS could be the same.
comments.subject: Re: QBing for the Jets

comments.article:
I'm a Syracuse grad/fan, and the hub-bub from upstate is that Marrone already has a deal in place to coach the Jets. Might be BS, but it seems odd for someone to voluntarily leave an NFL coaching job without another lined up. He spent some time earlier in his career in the Jets organization, and apparently has some ties.

I have mixed feelings about him. He definitely turned the Orange around, but he left for the NFL after saying for years that the SU job was his 'dream'. I guess if I'm pissed by that - it means he's good at what he does. He did some good things with the Bills - given he didn't have a QB. Sounds familar.

Who knows, maybe he'll trade for Ryan Nassib? That was a joke.
comments.subject: Marrone
